overview.short: Trueperella pyogenes is a Gram-positive, pleomorphic non-spore-forming, non-motile rod associated with pyogenic infections, most commonly in animals but occasionally in human opportunistic infections.
overview.clinical_context: Often recovered from abscesses, wound infections, soft tissue infections, and polymicrobial sites; zoonotic exposure can be relevant.

species_markers.notes: Beta haemolysis on blood agar supports T. pyogenes in the appropriate clinical context.
Supports differentiation from many catalase-positive coryneform organisms.
Growth under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions helps separate from strict anaerobes.

common_confusions.reason: Pleomorphic Gram-positive rods with overlapping colony appearance; needs confirmatory ID.
Clinical context and haemolysis can overlap; taxonomy history can cause confusion.

when_to_question_identification: Catalase positivity suggests Corynebacterium rather than Trueperella.
No haemolysis or gamma haemolysis may argue against pyogenes (consider other Trueperella/related genera).
Strict anaerobic-only growth suggests a different organism.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Ensures beta haemolysis is reproducible and correctly read.
Best routine method for species confirmation.
Definitive resolution when MALDI is ambiguous or for epidemiologic confirmation.
